questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the clinic with symptoms of numbness and tingling in the median nerve distribution of the hand. During the examination, the physician discusses the anatomy of the wrist and flexor retinaculum. Which of the following structures does NOT pass under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radial Artery

 

Option C:

 

  • This is the case of carpal tunnel syndrome which occurs due to compression of median nerve below the flexor retinacula.

 

 

 

 

  • 5 structures passes above flexor retinacula shown in image:

 

 

 

  • From image it’s clear that radial artery has no relation with flexor retinacula. Superficial branch of radial artery passes above flexor retinacula. Hence answer is Option C.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexor Digitorum Superficialis tendons pass under the flexor retinaculum. They are part of the tendons that travel through the carpal tunnel and are involved in flexing the fingers.

 

Option B. Median Nerve also travels under the flexor retinaculum. It is a significant structure within the carpal tunnel and is responsible for the sensory and motor innervation of parts of the hand.

 

Option D. The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus also pass under the flexor retinaculum. Like the flexor digitorum superficialis, these tendons are involved in the flexion of the fingers and travel through the carpal tunnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radial Artery, one of the major arteries of the forearm, does not pass under the flexor retinaculum.
  • It travels on the lateral side of the forearm and wrist and does not enter the carpal tunnel.
  • Radial artery enters the palmar surface of the hand by passing between two heads of the first dorsal interossei.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 131

questions.text: A 45-year-old office worker complains of persistent wrist pain and difficulty performing repetitive tasks on a computer keyboard. Physical examination reveals tenderness at the wrist joint and decreased range of motion, particularly during wrist flexion and extension. Radiographic evaluation shows evidence of degenerative changes in the joint space. Which of the following bones is NOT directly involved in the formation of the wrist joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulna

 

Option B:

 

  • In this question the examiner is trying to ask bone forming the wrist bone. Bones which participate in formation of wrist joint include - Radius, Scaphoid, Lunate, Triquetral
  • Ulna does not contribute to the wrist joint formation.
  • An articular disc separates the ulna from cavity of wrist joint as shown in image:

 

 

  • The carpus / wrist is formed by 8 carpal bones.
  • These are arranged in two rows. (Mnemonic : “She Looks Too Pretty, Try To Catch Her”)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scaphoid takes part in the formation of wrist joint.

 

Option C. Lower end of radius participates in the formation of wrist joint.

 

Option D. Triquetral also participates in the formation of wrist joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

Wrist joint is an ellipsoid joint formed by articulation between lower end of radius and scaphoid, lunate and triquetral.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 153

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect about the pointed Area A in the given image except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Floor is formed by styloid process of radius, base of first metacarpal bone

 

Option B:

 

  • The question says choose which of the following is incorrect except, i.e., the students needs to choose which of the following is correct 
  • The pointed area A in the given image is Anatomical Snuff Box (ASB)
  • All the statements given are incorrect except option B.
  • Floor of ASB is formed by-
    • Styloid Process of Radius
    • Scaphoid
    • Trapezium
    • Base of 1st Metacarpal

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The anatomical snuffbox is located on the dorsal (back) aspect of the hand and becomes more prominent when the thumb is hyperextended.

 

 

Option C.

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The postero medial border or boundary of the anatomical snuffbox is indeed formed by the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus muscle. This muscle plays a role in extending the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

 

Option D.

 

  • This statement is also incorrect. The antero lateral border or boundary of the anatomical snuffbox is indeed formed by the tendon of the abductor pollicis longus and Extensor pollicis brevis. This muscle extends the wrist and abducts the hand.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Anatomical Snuff Box (ASB) - From proximal to distal, floor is formed by the styloid process of radius, scaphoid, trapezium and base of first metacarpal bone. Radial artery crosses the floor.
  • Postero - Medial border is formed by - EPL (Extensor pollicis longus)
  • Antero - lateral border is formed by - EPB (extensor pollices brevis) & APL (Abductor pollicis longus)
     

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 101

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was referred to the emergency room after a fall from height on stretched left wrist. Pain, tenderness were noticed in the region of the anatomical snuff box of her left hand. X-ray showed fracture of scaphoid bone. Identify the correct statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones totally

 

Option B:

 

  • Scaphoid bone articulates with Radius (proximally), Trapezium & Trapezoid (distally), Lunate and Head of Capitate (medially).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Scaphoid fractures actually have a relatively high incidence of non-union.
  • This is due to the peculiar blood supply of the scaphoid, where the blood enters the bone distally and travels proximally.

 

 

  • In case of a fracture, especially in the proximal part, this can lead to avascular necrosis and non-union.

 

 

Option C.

 

  • Immobilization of the scaphoid bone can be challenging due to its location and the range of movements in the wrist.
  • Proper healing often requires a specific type of cast or splint known as GLASS HOLDING CAST that immobilizes not just the wrist but also the thumb, as movement of the thumb can disturb the scaphoid.

 

 

Option D.

 

  • In scaphoid fractures, it's typically the proximal fragment that is at risk of losing its blood supply, not the distal fragment.
  • This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally and travels proximally.
  • If there is a fracture, especially in the proximal part, it can compromise the blood flow to the proximal fragment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones Totally: The scaphoid bone, one of the carpal bones in the wrist, articulates with five other bones: the radius proximally; the trapezium distally on the thumb side; and the lunate, capitate, and trapezoid on its ulnar side.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 868

questions.text: An eight-year-old male child managed to take his board game from the loft after standing on top of two chairs one over the other. But while trying to get down, he fell down from the topmost and experienced severe pain over his right hand, back & leg. The image given is his x-ray. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the given case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pisiform bone is not seen in this x-ray

 

Option C:

 

  • Pisiform is sesamoid bone, smallest carpal bone & last carpal bone to ossify.
  • It ossify between 9 to 12 years of age.
  • Since the age of child is 8 years hence it is not ossified & not visible in X ray.

 

Ossification of carpal bones are shown in sequence in image below:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The scaphoid is not the largest carpal bone; capitate is the largest carpal bone.

 

Option B. Trapezium is also not the the largest carpal bone.

 

Option D. Pisiform is the smallest carpal bone, not the Lunate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pisiform bone is the: 
    • Smallest Bone
    • Last Bone to ossify (12th year)
    • Sesamoid Bone (within the tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris)
    • Capitate is the largest of carpal bones and starts ossification first.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 29

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman sustained a fall on the outstretched hand. She developed pain, tenderness and swelling over the dorsal aspect of her right wrist. She experienced difficulty in performing movements at the wrist. X-ray showed fracture of lower end of lateral bone of forearm. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

Option D. None of the above- this is the correct option because both the statements (Option & B) are incorrect.

 

Explanation:

 

The type of dislocation is always ascertained by the displacement of distal fragment and not proximal, i.e., if the distal fragment has displaced anteriorly and proximal fragment has displaced posteriorly - the dislocation will be reffered to as anterior and vice versa.

 

Option A.

 

  • Colles Fracture is defined as the fracture of distal end of radius with dorsal (posterior) displacement of distal fragment along with upwards pulling of distal fragment including the styloid process.
  • This is called dinner fork deformity. Because of this shortening the styloid process of radius and ulna are more or less in line with each other. So, therefore the statement given in Option A is incorrect.

 

Option B.

 

  • Smith’s fracture  is defined as the fracture of distal end of radius with ventral (anterior) displacement of distal fragment including the styloid process.,
  • Smith’s fracture is a fracture of the distal end of the radius and occurs from a fall on the back of hand.
  • It is also called reverse Colles or Garden spade deformity. So, therefore the statement given in the option B is also incorrect.

 

 

Option C. Option C can’t be correct since Both A and B options are incorrect.
Since All the options (A,B,C) are incorrect - None of the above is the correct answer
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 861

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes is admitted to the hospital with complaints of weakness in the hand and difficulty holding objects. The patient's medical history includes a recent cerebrovascular accident (CVA). A "card test" is performed as part of the neurological examination. Which of the following muscle groups is primarily assessed with this test to check for motor function in the hand?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmar Interossei

 

Option B:

 

  • Palmar interossei causes adduction of digits. (Mnemonic: PAD- Palmer interossei are adductor)
  • They are responsible for adducting the fingers towards the middle finger.  The card test is used to assess the function of the palmar interossei.
  • During this test, a patient is asked to hold a card between two fingers. Difficulty in holding the card can indicate weakness in the palmar interossei, which would compromise the adduction strength of the fingers.

 

 

  • Card test is done to test adduction of fingers by palmar interossei.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Lumbricals are involved in flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints.
  • The lumbricals are not directly tested by the card test. This test is more focused on the adduction and abduction of fingers, which are not the primary actions of the lumbricals.

 

 

Option C.

 

  • Dorsal Interossei are responsible for abducting the fingers away from the midline. 
  • While the dorsal interossei are important for finger movements, they are primarily involved in abduction, not adduction. Therefore, they are not the primary focus of the card test.

 

 

 

Option D.

 

  • Adductor Pollicis is responsible for adducting the thumb.
  • This muscle is not specifically evaluated by the card test. The adductor pollicis is typically tested by other maneuvers, such as asking the patient to grip something between the thumb and another finger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Palmar Interossei are responsible for adducting the fingers towards the middle finger. The card test is used to assess the function of the palmar interossei.
  • During this test, a patient is asked to hold a card between two fingers. Difficulty in holding the card can indicate weakness in the palmar interossei, which would compromise the adduction strength of the fingers.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 170

questions.text: Which muscle does not take part in dorsal digital expansion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adductor Pollicis

 

Option D:

 

  • Adductor pollicis inserts into the proximal phalanx of the thumb and is innervated by deep branch of the ulnar nerve and doesn’t contribute to extensor expansion.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Interossei are the proximal wing tendons.

 

Option B. Lumbricals are the distal wing tendons.

 

Option C. Extensor expansion inserts into the dorsal aspect of the proximal, middle and distal phalanx.

 

Educational objective:

 

Adductor pollicis inserts into the proximal phalanx of the thumb and is innervated by deep branch of the ulnar nerve and doesn’t contribute to extensor expansion.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 131

questions.text: A 54-year-old man had noticed during the past 3 months a thickening of the skin at the base of his right ring finger, which tried to pull his finger towards palm. He consulted his physician. On examination of the palms of both hands, a localized thickening of subcutaneous tissue could be felt at the base of the right ring and little fingers. The metacarpophalangeal joint of the ring finger could not be fully extended, either actively or passively. Identify the incorrect statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Each slip is attached to the Base of the Middle Phalanx and to the Fibrous Flexor Sheath of each finger

 

Option C:

 

  • The palmar aponeurosis is thickening of the deep fascia of the palm. It is attached to the base of the proximal phalanx and fibrous flexor sheath of each finger.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Dupuytren's Contracture is characterized by progressive thickening and shortening of the palmar fascia, leading to flexion contractures of the fingers, commonly the ring and little fingers.
  • The symptoms described, including the thickening of the skin at the base of the ring finger and the inability to fully extend the metacarpophalangeal joint, align with Dupuytren's contracture.

 

Option B.

 

  • The palmar aponeurosis is indeed a thickening of the deep fascia in the palm of the hand. It plays a key role in the structure and function of the hand, and its pathological thickening and contraction are central to Dupuytren's contracture.

 

Option D.

 

  • The palmar aponeurosis distally divides into slips that extend towards the fingers. While the number of slips can vary, typically, it divides into four or five slips extending towards the digits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Dupuytren's contracture, the pathological changes occur in the palmar aponeurosis and related structures.
  • However, the palmar aponeurosis does not normally attach to the base of the middle phalanx. Instead, it primarily attaches to the bases of the proximal phalanges and the overlying skin.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 86
